name: C++ Queue
description: Queues are a type of container adaptor, specifically designed to operate in a FIFO context (first-in first-out), where elements are inserted into one end of the container and extracted from the other

Member Functions.val: Returns whether the queue is empty
Returns the number of elements in the queue
Returns a reference to the next element in the queue
Returns a reference to the last element in the queue. This is the 'new' element in the queue
Inserts a new element at the end of the queue, after its current last element
Adds a new element at the end of the queue, after its current last element. This new element is constructed in place passing args as the arguments for its constructor (C++11 only)
Removes the next element in the queue, effectively reducing its size by one
Exchanges the contents of the container adaptor (*this) by those of x (C++11 only)

Function Overloads.val: Compares the contents of the underlying containers of two container adaptors. The comparison is done by applying the corresponding operator to the underlying containers
Exchanges the contents of x and y (C++11 only)

Helper Classes.val: Provides a transparent specialization of the std::uses_allocator type trait for std::queue: the container adaptor uses allocator if and only if the underlying container does (C++11 only)
